text: Its very inconsistent in frequency, sometimes no issues for weeks, and sometimes suddenly a spike in these (often in the weirder U20 South American matches etc). Annoying because it's frequent enough for it to become laborious to dispute so often I end up just letting it go (it's also hard to prove unless you have a proper timestamped feed of goals) so you rely on the traders giving you time of day to check them out. It feels like we're in a period of heightened occurrences though.

elements.text: Its very inconsistent in frequency, sometimes no issues for weeks, and sometimes suddenly a spike in these (often in the weirder U20 South American matches etc). It feels like we're in a period of heightened occurrences though.

I don't read this so negatively. He's had a good run and now he's fed up with it and ready to move on. Good luck to him.

text: In isolation, perhaps. However, as part of a growing number of voices saying the same thing and finding evidence of that in the markets I participate in, I find it very concerning

elements.text: In isolation, perhaps. However, as part of a growing number of voices saying the same thing and finding evidence of that in the markets I participate in, I find it very concerning

text:
Yeah I recognise that there's a difference between being ready to move on and seeing something you're still into dwindling as an opportunity.

Are there a growing number of voices though? There have always been a lot and we now connect with a wider pool of people than was the case even 10 years ago. People losing motivation and getting left behind is part of the cycle and comes to all of us in the end.

elements.text:

text: I'm not disputing declining liquidity, it's assuredly the case that at least some markets are diminishing. I'm not so sure that that's a concern though. It might be or it might not.

elements.text: I'm not disputing declining liquidity, it's assuredly the case that at least some markets are diminishing. I'm not so sure that that's a concern though. It might be or it might not.

text: I do think it's more complex than just total volumes matched (as Mark alludes to in his blog post). Cricket is apparently matching record volumes (ahead of footie so far this year I'm told), so it's probably more likely that markets are just acting more efficiently, and this might be what some suffering professionals are feeling as “poor match rates” or in other words it's harder to get matched at the value prices that they want to like they used to. This might be combined with less recreational money being around, but only Betfair will know about that.
